items.title: How I Built A $1M/Year Business - And Helped My Parents Retire

ai.summary: Based on the available description, when he was 15 Tuan Le vowed to help his parents retire after his family emigrated from Vietnam to Toronto in 2015. Ten years later his social video production company, ShortsCut, is generating over $1 million USD a year in sales, and he now pays his parents' rent and living expenses so they no longer have to work full time.
bullets: Tuan Le promised at 15 to help his parents after emigrating from Vietnam to Toronto in 2015.
He founded ShortsCut, a social video production company.
ShortsCut brings in over $1 million USD per year in sales.
Le now covers his parents' rent and living expenses so they stopped working full time.
Video produced & edited by Zach Green; reporting by Kamaron McNair.
takeaways: So what: A single successful social video company can scale to seven-figure annual revenue, indicating robust demand for short-form video content.
So what: Continued growth in digital media businesses suggests steady workload for content-hosting and delivery services.
So what: Media companies reaching this scale may drive predictable, ongoing requirements for storage, bandwidth, and processing capacity.
So what: Investments in reliable infrastructure can support creators and agencies that become significant recurring-revenue customers.

items.title: AI w cenach transferowych â€“ jak wykorzystaÄ‡ jej potencjaÅ‚? | Monika Palmowska, Jakub Roszkiewicz

ai.summary: Based on the available descriptionâ€¦ AI is already transforming transfer pricing by enabling profitability monitoring, comparative analyses and automation of documentation. In the KPMG ON AIR episode experts Monika Palmowska and Jakub Roszkiewicz discuss how AI can strengthen (not replace) tax advisors, associated risks (data, security, RODO, hallucinations), and practical implementation steps including secure environments, ERP integration and the need to organize processes first.
bullets: AI use cases: rentability monitoring, comparable analyses and automated transfer pricing documentation.
AI complements advisors and supports development of junior staff rather than replacing experts.
Main risks highlighted: data protection, security, GDPR compliance and model hallucinations.
Digital Gateway and ERP integration presented as enablers for secure, intelligent benchmarking and workflows.
Recommended implementation steps: start with process organization and follow defined pillars of AI adoption.
takeaways: Provide a secure, compliant environment (akin to Digital Gateway) to host AI workflows for transfer pricing.
Prioritize data governance and GDPR controls to mitigate security and hallucination risks.
Ensure ERP integration and access to benchmarking data for effective AI-driven analyses.
Leverage automation to reduce manual tasks while keeping human oversight and advisory judgment.
Standardize and organize transfer pricing processes before scaling AI implementation.
